articles.headline: Top Defense Officials Seek to End ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
articles.snippet: Adm. Mike Mullen and Defense Secretary Robert Gates told a Senate panel they would review how to institute a policy allowing openly gay people to serve in the military.
articles.abstract: Adm. Mike Mullen and Defense Secretary Robert Gates told a Senate panel they would review how to institute a policy allowing openly gay people to serve in the military.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The nation’s top two defense officials called Tuesday for an end to the 16-year-old “don’t ask, don’t tell” law, a major step toward allowing openly gay men and women to serve in the United States military for the first time.

articles.headline: After Massacre, Guinea Sees Hope of Lifted Chains
articles.snippet: A rare thing occurred in an area often given to autocracy: a peaceful transfer of power, months after a massacre.
articles.abstract: A rare thing occurred in an area often given to autocracy: a peaceful transfer of power, months after a massacre.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONAKRY, Guinea  Something rare has happened in a region often given to brutal autocracy: power has been peacefully transferred to a civilian, just four months after an army massacre that recalled the worst of Africa’s past.

articles.headline: Dodd Calls Obama Plan Too Grand
articles.snippet: Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, was told that the Obama administration’s new proposals to rein in Wall Street firms could derail negotiations over financial regulations.
articles.abstract: Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, was told that the Obama administration’s new proposals to rein in Wall Street firms could derail negotiations over financial regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee warned on Tuesday that the Obama administration’s new proposals to rein in Wall Street firms ran the risk of derailing months of delicate negotiations over overhauling financial regulations.

articles.headline: No Help in Sight, More Homeowners Walk Away
articles.snippet: By June, about 5.1 million people will own a home whose value is below 75 percent of what is owed.
articles.abstract: By June, about 5.1 million people will own a home whose value is below 75 percent of what is owed.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2006, Benjamin Koellmann bought a condominium in Miami Beach. By his calculation, it will be about the year 2025 before he can sell his modest home for what he paid. Or maybe 2040.

articles.headline: $100 Million Bonus Plan at A.I.G. Draws Fire
articles.snippet: The giant insurer and recipient of the biggest government bailout in history agreed to cut its next round of bonuses by $20 million.
articles.abstract: The giant insurer and recipient of the biggest government bailout in history agreed to cut its next round of bonuses by $20 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American International Group has agreed to cut employee bonuses by $20 million and will distribute about $100 million on Wednesday, according to people with knowledge of the negotiations.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Sewell Chan

articles.headline: Gates Tries to Get F-35 Program Back on Course
articles.snippet: Rather than being the Chevrolet of the skies, the F-35 has turned into the Pentagon’s biggest budget-buster.
articles.abstract: Rather than being the Chevrolet of the skies, the F-35 has turned into the Pentagon’s biggest budget-buster.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Joint Strike Fighter was supposed to be the program that broke the mold, proof that the Pentagon could build something affordable, dependable and without much drama.

articles.headline: In Court, Impassioned Challenges of Madoff Trustee’s Plans
articles.snippet: A bankruptcy judge is acting as King Solomon over an issue that will require him to hurt some victims of Bernard Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: A bankruptcy judge is acting as King Solomon over an issue that will require him to hurt some victims of Bernard Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: No one would ever mistake the cramped, unadorned Manhattan courtroom of Judge Burton R. Lifland for King Solomon’s court.

articles.headline: Soldier Deaths Draw Focus to U.S. in Pakistan
articles.snippet: The presence of U.S. soldiers, mainly for intelligence and training, has been handled with discretion.
articles.abstract: The presence of U.S. soldiers, mainly for intelligence and training, has been handled with discretion.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The deaths of three American soldiers in a Taliban suicide attack on Wednesday lifted the veil on United States military assistance to Pakistan that the authorities here would like to keep quiet and the Americans, as the donors, chafe at not receiving credit for.
